ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: There were only live virtual lectures.
n/a
n/a
n/a
For this class we only attended live virtual seminars.
Just the live virtual lecture
live lectures supplemented with intermittent virtual breakout rooms of 3-5 students
YouTube videos
Also used live virtual discussion rooms to break down problems
Canvas assignments and practice problems.
recorded review lectures, live virtual peer tutor sessions

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned about calc 2 and all of the ways we can use it to solve real problems such as finding the volume of shapes.
Basic knowledge of Riemann sums, integrals, sequences, series (Taylor, McClaurin), volumes of irregular shapes.
I have deepened my skills in integral calculus as well as critical thinking and problem solving. This class exposed me to the mathematical foundation behind many career fields.
I developed my calculus abilities and knowledge.
I have gained knowledge of single variable calculus and its application.
Felt like i learned the skills listed in the syllabus
I furthered my knowledge in calculus and took my first and hopefully last math class of college.
I learned how to effectively study for calculus assessments, and I also gained a better understanding of solids of revolution and the various methods to solve integrals.

Aside from the actual material, I learned how to maintain a level of focus and adapt to a virtual model of learning. It gave me the skills on how to complete more complex mathematical problems and understand math on a deeper conceptual level.
integral calculus, self-studying
To spend more time on this subject
I better learned how to think analytically and attack mathematical problems.

I developed a deeper understanding of concepts reviewed in Calculus II, and the course also delved into real-world applications of calculus that were very beneficial to visualizing and better grasping the material.
Deep understanding of integrals, and in the end we learnt about revolution and volumes.
Calculus
I learned more about calculus.
I easily absorbed all the contents of this course. I was able to understand the "whys" of calculus topics unlike in high school, where I learned the techniques.
I learned how to do derivatives and integrals. I also learned a bit about polar coordinates and parametric equations.
Calculus 2
I developed a greater knowledge of single variable calculus and strengthened my logical and problem-solving skills.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The biggest strength of the course was that my teacher was extremely good. The material is very difficult, but he did a good job of teaching and making sure our questions were answered. I think the biggest weakness is that outside help was relatively limited.

This class was very well structured and planned; assignments and lectures nearly always followed the schedule, which made it easy to keep up with. However, one weakness was the variance in instruction/lack of interconnectedness between various professors. This was most evident during the pre-exam review sessions, which would lead to confusion in times of preparation for exams. This could be fixed by increasing communication regarding teaching material between professors.
The classes are overall well structured and allows sufficient time for discussions.
No real weaknesses of this course. Everything was planned carefully and there were always resources available if I needed extra help
Brett was great. helped out a lot, though 1-1 time is critical to do well.

I'm not sure there are any improvements to be made, it can be hard to focus in online lectures but that is a matter of zoom and not anything that can be fixed. There are lots of explorations, office hours, and videos to help fill in gaps you might have in the subject matter and if you are good/okay at math and you try then you should be fine.
Strengths include the Explorations, Concept Checks, review sessions, peer tutors, and the (conveniently-timed) office hours. I have no weaknesses to report!

My strengths were integration and volumes. For the most part, I understood how to integrate problems and compute volumes beyond the basic level. I understood how to do each of those problems thoroughly I felt. My weaknesses were in the area of series and sequences. I did not fully grasp how to do these problems as well as I did other topics.

I think the math department suffered the most from the limitations of online instruction. I think there is a mismatch in what is taught in the course and what is assessed on the test. The course instruction focuses so much time on broad concepts or applications, whereas the tests are strictly computation, often of types of problems we've not seen before. A greater focus on computation would improve the course.

Weakness: Too much material, too little time. 
Strength: Brett Smith is very helpful and nice!

The strength of this course is definitely the homework structure with smaller regular checkin assignments and problem sets once a week. The weaknesses are not having recorded lectures which can leave students confused or behind if they are unable to attend class for a day.

The course material was structured, and the theoretical aspects of the concepts were thoroughly explained; the links between differential and integral calculus were made very clear, which helped with the conceptual side of the course. At times, the course material felt a bit rushed, especially with regards to the parametric/polar unit, which were left until the last week or two of class. I feel as though we could have been given more opportunities to demonstrate learning and improvement, in addition to the midterm and final exams.
The course is very well-structures and the psets and exams are very good representation of your understanding of the material discussed in the class.
No recorded lectures to look back on if I had internet issues.

Strengths: easy to follow, professor is very clear and answers all questions, lecture targets exactly what may be confusing
Weaknesses: none
A strength is the amount of support a student gets when they are struggling. I was very happy with how much help i got and continued to receive throughout the semester.
Perhaps less of the quizzes before class as I never had time to do them

I think the weaknesses of this course was student engagement. the lectures were sometimes hard to stay focused on and felt like a lot of information to take in and not get distracted especially over the computer. This course was well explained and easy to understand.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course worked well. We had breakout rooms and large lectures.

The Jamboard platform utilized both during class and in office hours was a great tool for working on problems together in groups and maintaining a record of what we did. In class, I think it would be good to keep the same breakout room groups throughout the semester to make working on problems  more comfortable and enjoyable.
I really appreciate the class polls. It is a fun way to make the course more interactive.
Brett's use of breakout rooms was extremely helpful.

I really enjoyed the Explorations because I felt prepared before entering class! I also liked the Jamboard breakout rooms, but I would suggest only 1 per class or to switch groups more often because my group didn't interact as much, so they didn't contribute to my learning. I didn't look forward to meeting with them, which caused me to become less active during breakout room time.

I felt Brett did a great job keeping the class engages using polls and asking questions despite the fact that some cameras were off. Although, I feel like it was hard to focus at times. There's nothing really more Brett or anyone could have done, it's just harder to maintain focus for a virtual course rather than in person.

Office hours were helpful, although they could be greatly improved by implementing a ticket system, such that students have some amount of one-on-one time. In group office hours, some students dominate the question-asking.
unsure
The practices that succeeded were definitely the discussion sections within class, they allowed individuals to dissect what was going on. I dont think there were any practices that could be improved.
Recording the live lectures would be tremendously helpful.
Breakout rooms helped me figure out how to solve certain problems with the help of others and better grasp the material
Breakout rooms

Success: Having recorded review sessions were helpful; using a tablet, instead of paper, to lecture was effective 

Improvement: Having peer tutor sessions would be helpful for extra explanation
The quizzes before class really helped, but I wish we had recorded lectures.
I think the use of jam board and breakout rooms was effective in this course though and helped to aid In student engagement.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If a student just wants to take a math class for fun, I would not recommend this class. That being said, if a student wants to really challenge themselves with a higher level of math, I think this course is great.
Yes; the course does a great job of teaching the basics of Calculus.

I would recommend this course to another student if they are interested in entering any STEM field. It teaches both the skills and content necessary for success across a multitude of disciplines. While challenging, learning and mastering the material is definitely fulfilling.
Yes. I think it offers clear explanations and systematic learning of single variable calculus.
If you like math/need to take the course then take it! If you don't like math, don't take it. If you can fulfill the a requirement with a lower math course then I would take the lower level.
I would recommend this course to a student only if they can get a good instructor for their section.

I would recommend this course to students who have already taken BC AP Calculus in high school. I believe it strengthens your current math capabilities and prepares you for Math 120. If you have never taken BC AP Calculus, I wouldn't recommend this course because we go through content very fast, so it may be difficult to catch up.

I would recommend this course to a student who is good at and enjoys math. This class presents intellectually challenging concepts and problems that those students would enjoy. However, I would not recommend this course to someone who doesn't enjoy math. It would be hard to maintain a focus level that would help you succeed.

I would not unless required. The sad fact is that I learned more from YouTube videos than from my instructor. Seriously, the amount of work and time required is just not proportional to the amount you'll gain through this course. Get a copy of the syllabus and go down the list of concepts yourself, self-studying, and you'll walk away with an equal grasp of the material without sinking a slot into this class.
Yes it is required for most majors, standard math class.
Yes i would. This was an engaging and thorough course that properly taught me the material advertised.

Yes! It may be beneficial to take the course if you have already taken AP Calculus BC (or equivalent) in high school to refresh yourself on the material, but even if that is not the case, this course is definitely manageable.
Yes definitely. I did not enjoy math before, but this course is very well organized and all the applications were very useful.
Yes, the Instructor Brett Smith is brilliant
It was a pretty good course overall and the professor made it easy to learn.
I would if they really like math or need it for pre-med requirements
Yes it is a good calculus class and is quite rigorous. You become better at calc
I would, the concepts are difficult but I think the teacher was very good at explaining difficult concepts.
